sen.j: 狂歌（きょうか）とは、社会風刺や皮肉、滑稽を盛り込み、五・七・五・七・七の音で構成した短歌（和歌）のパロディ形式。
sen.e: Kyoka is a parody of tanka (Japanese poem) that contains social satire, irony, and humor in thirty-one (five-seven-five-seven-seven) syllables.
Kyoka is a parody of tanka (Japanese poem) that contains social satire, irony, and humor in 31 (5-7-5-7-7) syllables.
Kyoka is a parody of tanka (Japanese poem) that contains social satire, irony, and humor in 31 (5-7-5-7-7) syllables.

sen.j: 狂歌の起こりは古代・中世にさかのぼる。
sen.e: The origin of kyoka can be traced back to the ancient and medieval period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The origin of kyoka can be traced back to the ancient and medieval period.
The origin of kyoka can be traced back to the ancient and medieval period.

sen.j: 狂歌という言葉自体は平安時代に用例があるという。
sen.e: The term "Kyoka" is found in documents from the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The term "Kyoka" is found in documents from the Heian period.
The term "Kyoka" is found in documents from the Heian period.

sen.j: 落書（らくしょ）などもその系譜に含めて考えることができるが、独自のジャンルとして発達したのは江戸時代中期で、享保頃に上方で活躍した鯛屋貞柳などが知られる。
sen.e: While rakusho (lampoon) can be in the same category, Kyoka was established as a unique genre during the mid Edo period, and among famous Kyoka poets was Teiryu TAIYA who was active in Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area) during the Kyoho era.

While rakusho (lampoon) can be in the same category, Kyoka was established as a unique genre during the mid Edo period, and among famous Kyoka poets was Teiryu TAIYA, who was active in Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area) during the Kyoho era.

While rakusho (lampoon) can be in the same category, Kyoka was established as a unique genre during the mid Edo period, and among famous Kyoka poets was Teiryu TAIYA, who was active in Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area) during the Kyoho era.

sen.j: 文化史上、特筆されるのは江戸の天明狂歌ブームである。
sen.e: In the history of Japanese culture, a fad of Kyoka during the Tenmei era in the Edo period deserves special mention.
In the history of Japanese culture, a Kyoka fad during the Tenmei era in the Edo period deserves special mention.
In the history of Japanese culture, a Kyoka fad during the Tenmei era in the Edo period deserves special mention.

sen.j: 田沼時代の始まる1767年（明和4年）に狂詩集『寝惚先生文集』が刊行されたのがブームのきっかけとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the fad started when a collection of Kyoka entitled "Neboke sensei bunshu (the Literary Works of Master Groggy)" was published in 1767 at the beginning of Okitsugu TANUMA's political control.

It is said that the fad started when a collection of Kyoka entitled "Neboke sensei bunshu (the Literary Works of Master Groggy)" was published in 1767 at the beginning of Okitsugu TANUMA's political control.

It is said that the fad started when a collection of Kyoka entitled "Neboke sensei bunshu (the Literary Works of Master Groggy)" was published in 1767 at the beginning of Okitsugu TANUMA's political control.

sen.j: 序文を平賀源内が寄せ、筆者は当時19歳の大田南畝（四方赤良、蜀山人）であった。
sen.e: With a preface written by Gennai HIRAGA, this book was written by nineteen-year-old Nanbo OTA (a.k.a. YOMO no Akara and Shokusanjin).
With a preface written by Gennai HIRAGA, this book was written by 19 year old Nanbo OTA (a.k.a. YOMO no Akara and Shokusanjin).
With a preface written by Gennai HIRAGA, this book was written by 19 year old Nanbo OTA (a.k.a. YOMO no Akara and Shokusanjin).

sen.j: 1769年に唐衣橘洲の屋敷で狂歌会が開かれた。
sen.e: In1769, the first Kyoka gathering was held on the premises of Kisshu KARAGOROMO.
In1769, the first Kyoka gathering was held on the premises of Kisshu KARAGOROMO.
In1769, the first Kyoka gathering was held on the premises of Kisshu KARAGOROMO.

sen.j: これ以降、狂歌の愛好者らはグループ（狂歌連）を作って創作に励んだ。
sen.e: Since then, Kyoka lovers had formed groups (Kyoka-ren) to create kyoka poems.
Since then, Kyoka lovers formed groups (Kyoka-ren) to create kyoka poems.
Since then, Kyoka lovers formed groups (Kyoka-ren) to create kyoka poems.

sen.j: 朱楽菅江、宿屋飯盛（石川雅望）らの名もよく知られている。
sen.e: The other famous Kyoka poems include Kanko AKERA and Meshimori YADOYA (Masamochi ISHIKAWA).
sen.cmt: 「石川雅望（石川雅望）」はWeb表記では「宿屋飯盛（石川雅望）」でしたのでこちらに修正しました。
sen.e: Other famous Kyoka poets include Kanko AKERA and Meshimori YADOYA (Masamochi ISHIKAWA).
Other famous Kyoka poets include Kanko AKERA and Meshimori YADOYA (Masamochi ISHIKAWA).

sen.j: 田沼時代は狂歌ブームのほか浮世絵、黄表紙などの隆盛が見られ、江戸文化の一つのピークをなしている。
sen.e: The Edo culture was at its peak during the era of TANUMA administration with Kyoka, Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) and kibyoshi (an illustrated book of popular fiction whose cover is yellow) were flourishing.

The Edo culture was at its peak during the TANUMA administration, when Kyoka, Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) and kibyoshi (an illustrated book of popular fiction whose cover is yellow) flourished.

The Edo culture was at its peak during the TANUMA administration, when Kyoka, Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) and kibyoshi (an illustrated book of popular fiction whose cover is yellow) flourished.

sen.j: 狂歌には、古今集などの名作をパロディ化した作品が多く見られる。
sen.e: Many kyoka poems are a parody of masterpieces such as Kokin Wakashu (a collection of ancient and modern Japanese poetry).
Many kyoka poems are parodies of masterpieces such as Kokin Wakashu (a collection of ancient and modern Japanese poetry).
Many kyoka poems are parodies of masterpieces such as Kokin Wakashu (a collection of ancient and modern Japanese poetry).

sen.j: これは短歌の本歌取りの手法を用いたものといえる。
sen.e: This is an application of Waka technique called Honkatori (writing poems quoted parts of old poems).
This is an application of a Waka technique called Honkatori (writing poems quoted parts of old poems).
This is an application of a Tanka technique called Honkatori (writing poems quoted parts of old poems).

sen.j: 近代以降、狂歌は全くふるわず、現在でも愛好者の多い川柳と対照的である。
sen.e: After the modern period, Kyoka has been very dull in contrast to Senryu (comic haiku) that is still enjoying the wide popularity today.
After the modern period, Kyoka has been very dull in contrast to Senryu (comic haiku), which still enjoys wide popularity today.
After the modern period, Kyoka has been very dull in contrast to Senryu (comic haiku), which still enjoys wide popularity today.

sen.j: 歌よみは下手こそよけれ天地の 動き出してたまるものかは（宿屋飯盛）
sen.e: The poorer a poet's work is, the better; the Heaven and the Earth should not be moved. (by Meshimori YADOYA)
The poorer a poet's work is, the better; Heaven and Earth should not be moved (by Meshimori YADOYA).
The poorer a poet's work is, the better; Heaven and Earth should not be moved (by Meshimori YADOYA).

sen.j: 古今和歌集仮名序の「力をもいれずして天地を動かし…」をふまえた作。
sen.e: A kyoka based on a phrase in the Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Japanese preface) "Without much strength the Heaven and the Earth would be moved…"
A kyoka based on a phrase in the Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Japanese preface) "Without much strength Heaven and Earth would be moved…"
A kyoka based on a phrase in the Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Japanese preface) "Without much strength Heaven and Earth would be moved…"

sen.j: 世わたりに春の野に出て若菜つむ わが衣手の雪も恥かし
sen.e: To make my living; Go out to the field in Spring; and gather young herbs; the snow on my sleeves; must be ashamed
To make my living; Go out to the field in Spring; and gather young herbs; the snow on my sleeves; must be ashamed
To make my living; Go out to the field in Spring; and gather young herbs; the snow on my sleeves; must be ashamed

sen.j: 百人一首の光孝天皇の歌（君がため春の野に出でて若菜つむ わが衣手に雪は降りつつ）が元歌。
sen.e: The original poem was that of the Emperor Koko in Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets): "To give you; Go out to the field in Spring; and gather young herbs; the snow is falling on my sleeves."

The original poem was that of Emperor Koko in Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets): "To give you; Go out to the field in Spring; and gather young herbs; the snow is falling on my sleeves."

The original poem was that of Emperor Koko in Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets): "To give you; Go out to the field in Spring; and gather young herbs; the snow is falling on my sleeves."

sen.j: はたもとは今ぞ淋しさまさりけり 御金もとらず暮らすと思へば
sen.e: Hatamoto samurai are; now at the peak of emptiness; when they think of living without receiving salary.
Hatamoto samurai are; now at the peak of emptiness; when they think of living without receiving salary.
Hatamoto samurai are; now at the peak of emptiness; when they think of living without receiving salary.

sen.j: 享保の改革の際に詠まれたもので、旗本への給与が遅れたことを風刺している。
sen.e: This poem was written during the Kyoho reforms, satirizing the delay of salary to Hatamoto samurai.
This poem was written during the Kyoho reforms, satirizing the delay of salary to Hatamoto samurai.
This poem was written during the Kyoho reforms, satirizing the delay of salary to Hatamoto samurai.

sen.j: 「古今和歌集」源宗于の歌（山里は冬ぞ寂しさまさりける 人目も草も枯れぬと思へば）が元歌。
sen.e: The original poem was that of MINAMOTO no Muneyuki in Kokin Wakashu "Villages in the Mountain are; now at the peak of emptiness; when people and leaves are withered."
The original poem was that of MINAMOTO no Muneyuki in Kokin Wakashu "Villages in the Mountain are; now at the peak of emptiness; when people and leaves are withered."
The original poem was that of MINAMOTO no Muneyuki in Kokin Wakashu "Villages in the Mountain are; now at the peak of emptiness; when people and leaves are withered."

sen.j: 白河の清きに魚のすみかねて もとの濁りの田沼こひしき
sen.e: Of the Shirakawa River; in its clean flow; fishes are hard to live; the old Tanuma (muddy paddy); is what they are missing
Of the Shirakawa River; in its clean flow; fishes are hard to live; the old Tanuma (muddy paddy); is what they are missing
Of the Shirakawa River; in its clean flow; fishes are hard to live; the old Tanuma (muddy paddy); is what they are missing

sen.j: 寛政の改革の際に詠まれたもの。
sen.e: This poem was written during the Kansei Reform.
This poem was written during the Kansei Reform.
This poem was written during the Kansei Reform.

sen.j: 白河は松平定信の領地。
sen.e: Shirakawa was Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA's territory.
Shirakawa was Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA's territory.
Shirakawa was Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA's territory.

sen.j: 定信の厳しい改革より、その前の田沼意次の多少裏のあった政治の方が良かったことを風刺している。
sen.e: It satires that people thought the previous days of corrupt politics by Okitsugu TANUMA was better than harsh reform by Sadanobu.
It satirizes people who thought that old days of corrupt politics of Okitsugu TANUMA were better than the harsh reforms of Sadanobu.
It satirizes people who thought that old days of corrupt politics of Okitsugu TANUMA were better than the harsh reforms of Sadanobu.

sen.j: 大田南畝作という評判もあったが本人は否定した。
sen.e: It was rumored that Nanbo OTA wrote this poem but he denied.
It was rumored that Nanbo OTA wrote this poem but he denied it.
It was rumored that Nanbo OTA wrote this poem but he denied it.

sen.j: 泰平の眠りを覚ます上喜撰 たった四杯で夜も眠れず
sen.e: Peaceful sleep; was disturbed by Jokisen; Just four cups; brought sleepless nights
Peaceful sleep; was disturbed by Jokisen; Just four cups; brought sleepless nights
Peaceful sleep; was disturbed by Jokisen; Just four cups; brought sleepless nights

sen.j: 上喜撰とは玉露茶の商品名で、濃茶を飲むと興奮するように、たった四隻の外国船（蒸気船）に驚き、心配になることを風刺した。
sen.e: "Jokisen" was a product name of high-quality green tea, and as cups of strong green tea excite drinkers, this poem satirized those who were frightened and worried by just four jokisen (steam boats) from foreign countries.

"Jokisen" was a product name of high-quality green tea, and as cups of strong green tea excite drinkers, this poem satirized those who were frightened and worried by just four jokisen (steam boats) from foreign countries.

"Jokisen" was a product name of high-quality green tea, and as cups of strong green tea excite drinkers, this poem satirized those who were frightened and worried by just four jokisen (steam boats) from foreign countries.

sen.j: 大田南畝の率いる山の手連、唐衣橘洲らの四谷連など武士中心の連のほか、町人を中心としたものも多く、市川團十郎 (5代目)とその取り巻きが作った堺町連や、蔦屋重三郎ら吉原を中心にした吉原連などもあった。
sen.e: There were two types of Kyoka ren (groups): groups consisted mainly of samurai, such as Yamanote-ren led by Nanbo OTA and Yotsuya-ren with Kisshu KARAGOROMO; those consisted mainly of citizens, including Sakaimachi-ren formed by the Fifth Danjuro Ichikawa and his followers and Yoshiwara-ren led by Juzaburo TSUTAYA based in Yoshiwara.

There were two types of Kyoka ren (groups): groups made up mainly of samurai, such as Yamanote-ren led by Nanbo OTA and Yotsuya-ren with Kisshu KARAGOROMO; those made up mainly of citizens, including Sakaimachi-ren formed by the Fifth Danjuro Ichikawa and his followers, and Yoshiwara-ren led by Juzaburo TSUTAYA and based in Yoshiwara.
